I'm a chief marketing officer at open gov give you a little bit of a background of open gov actually a little
background on myself I actually started in the tech industry in 1987 as a programmer I guess you call them
engineers now and eventually moved into customer support and then into marketing and found my way to open gov about a
year ago and so open gov has been around since about 2012 actually built from the
ground up on AWS the history is much like a lot of startups in the Silicon Valley was a group of Stanford students
that decided it would be really cool coming out of the Great Recession and out of the California budget crisis to do some visualizations of data as well
as pension data to see you know to help the government see where things were going and detect problems and they went
to a bunch of governments including the state of California and asked for budget data and basically found out there was no way to get it and so you know these
this group decided hey this is a real problem in government we need to figure out a better way of getting this data
and visualizing it and so open gov was founded to do financial and performance intelligence and transparency and really
help governments use the cloud to operate better and fundamentally we see
three pervasive challenges that we're trying to solve for governments first increasing the spending power so you
know by looking at things like accountability how do how do government's become more accountable to
their citizens and therefore be able to have the freedom to use money and spend it on our behalf as well as providing
insights to be able to do a better job of understanding how other governments are spending money and ultimately
improve their operations efficiency governments we know are very much
paper-based they're bound by very old technology and a lot of people in a lot of roles spend an enormous amount of
time simply running reports distributing reports continuously updating data not very high value activities we think we
can make them more efficient and actually focus on strategy within those governments and last but not least preparing for the future we know that in
most governments around the world huge numbers upwards of fifty percent of people are past retirement age or due to
retire they know where all the data is kept within the government they need to get it in some place that can be handed
to the next generation at the same time the next generation are Millennials who expect to
be connected expect to be on mobile devices expect to be able to dive and dig into data and not have to go through
paper-based manuals and PDFs to understand how their government is performing so what we're doing is
basically building what we view as the connected government and our thinking here is that governments have always had to be connected early days it was
through what waterways and then railroads and expressways and if you were not on the network you really could
not thrive as a government the new network is the internet and the cloud and through that we see an opportunity
to connect government's within themselves so government employees like finance directors and city managers and
administrators at all sides of governments connecting them to their departments and to elected officials
then it's connecting governments to citizens so that they can do a better job of getting accountability so that
they can have the freedom to spend money and actually demonstrate the good that they're doing to the public and tell
their story in a much better way connecting governments to governments this is the true opportunity of the
cloud where more and more governments are putting data into cloud-based multi-tenant systems we can now use data
science to help them understand and gain insights from other governments and ultimately allow them to operate better
and spend money much more efficiently and last but not least governments to infrastructure so we all know the
Internet of Things is out there smart cities are popping up sensor data in our view our is basically the outcome of a
lot of government spending if you want to reduce traffic you spend money you budget for the reduction of traffic and
then you have to measure through sensors whether that's actually happening so our view then is to connect governments to
their infrastructures that they can bring all this data into one place and to do this we see a couple key
attributes first data-driven we need to figure out how to break down silos between very antiquated financial
systems some of them still green screen systems being run in many cities and counties throughout throughout the world
breaking that data down bringing it all together providing really smart simple
applications that help them visualize data at a very granular level enabling collaboration so that not just sharing
data and reports but actually collaborating and exchanging ideas and being able to do it between very
technical people and non-technical people and then last but not least making it easy one of the big learnings we've had
here is especially as you go out to some of the smaller government's in the country you need to be able to do it in such a way that they can adopt it very
very quickly and not without a lot of complexity and again that's where the cloud and AWS comes in and just to give
you a couple examples of the impact of this Bell California actually became one of our early customers right after a
multimillion-dollar scandal we're almost everybody in the City Council and the mayor went to jail for embezzling
millions and millions of dollars recently they came back to us and said because of us they've been able to
regain the trust of with their citizens because they are putting real-time data of very granular spending that their
public can actually look at and see that they're not in fact hiding dollars in places that wouldn't have been able to
detect if they just looked at a budget document in a PDF stanton california used open gov to convince the public to
fund an additional police officer for a human trafficking task force and actually has been credited with with
breaking a prostitution ring very recently so again you know this isn't just about providing pretty numbers this
is about really trying to change the way the government operates state of Ohio has actually purchased open gov for
